greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k), n>=3, 3<=k<=n, read by rows: T(n,k) = number of simple graphs on n labeled nodes, where each maximally connected subgraph consists of a single node or has a unique cycle of length k.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 3..102, flattened
example: T(4,4) = 4, because there are 4 simple graphs on 4 labeled nodes, where each maximally connected subgraph consists of a single node or has a unique cycle of length 4:
maple: B:= proc(n,c,k) option remember; if c=0 then 1 elif c<0 or n<c then 0 elif c=n then binomial(n-1,k-1) *(k-1)! /2 *n^(n-k) else B(n-1,c,k) +add(binomial(n-1,j) * B(j+1,j+1,k) *B(n-1-j,c-j-1,k), j=k-1..c-1) fi end: T:= (n,k)-> add(B(n,c,k), c=0..n): seq(seq(T(n,k), k=3..n), n=3..11);
mathematica: B[n_, c_, k_] := B[n, c, k] = Which[c == 0, 1, c<0 || n<c, 0, c == n, Binomial[n-1, k-1]*(k-1)!/2*n^(n-k), True, B[n-1, c, k] + Sum[Binomial[n-1, j]*B[j+1, j+1, k]*B[n-1-j, c-j-1, k], {j, k-1, c-1}]]; T[n_, k_] := Sum [B[n, c, k], {c, 0, n}]; Table[Table [T[n, k], {k, 3, n}], {n, 3, 11}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 21 2014, translated from _Alois P. Heinz_'s Maple code *)
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Sep 14 2008
